One of China's major strategic goals is clearly the establishment of sovereignty over the "Nine-Dash Line". There is a little more than three weeks until April 1st. I do not believe a lethal confrontation will occur in that time frame. While China continues to reclaim land in the South China Sea, there is no evidence to support an imminent confrontation over the reclamation. Tensions between the United States and China are escalating and military exercises are taking place due to the increased presence of the U.S. but there is no indication that a confrontation will occur between the People's Republic of China and those of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam.

Probability: 1% There is almost no chance that there will be a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of the People’s Republic of China and those of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam before 1 April 2021. This is the case, despite an ongoing war of words between involved parties and China’s aggressive continued expansion of its claimed territory. In its list of Conflicts to Watch in 2020, the Council on Foreign Relations listed “an armed confrontation over disputed maritime areas in the South China Sea between China and one or more Southeast Asian claimants (Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam)” as top priorities with a high impact and a moderate likelihood of occurrence (“Conflicts to Watch”). In January 2021, China passed a law allowing the China Coast Guard to fire on what it identifies as illegal foreign vessels in waters under its jurisdiction (Permal). The Philippines Foreign Affairs Secretary, Teodoro Locsin, Jr, suggested that the Philippine navy will shoot back – “If there is an incident, I can assure you there will be more than just a protest” (Seidel, “South China Sea”). In a US Department of State briefing on February 19, 2021, Department Spokesperson Ned Price said, “the United States joins the Philippines, Vietnam, Indonesia, Japan, and other countries in expressing concern with China’s recently enacted Coast Guard law, which may escalate ongoing territorial and maritime disputes.” He continued, “The United States reminds China of its obligations under the United Nations Charter to 
refrain from the threat or use of force, and to conform its maritime claims to the International Law of the Sea…We stand firm in our respective alliance commitments to Japan and the Philippines” (Price). Subsequent to China passing their new law, the US sent two Navy aircraft carrier strike groups to begin operations in the disputed waters of the South China Sea (“Two US Navy”). A week later, Britain, France, Germany, Holland, and Canada all announced that they are sending warships to the South China Sea in 
growing “pushback” against Beijing (Seidel, “British and Canadian”). While the increasing rhetoric between the parties increases the likelihood of a lethal confrontation, there are indicators that peaceful options are still on the table. However, with tensions running high, and according to the CFR, in a “worsening” status (“Global Conflict Tracker”) all it takes is one small incident for a situation to turn deadly.  However, things get interesting when we look at the hard numbers. According to the Center for Strategic & International Studies’ South China Sea Incident Tracker, incidents between China and others in the region have become less frequent, and in the past five years, incidents involving China have not resulted in deaths (China Power Team). 
2016 – 13 incidents, no deaths
2017 – 3 incidents, no deaths
2018 – 3 incidents, no deaths
2019 – 5 incidents, no deaths
2020 – 1 incident, no deaths Since this question specifically relates to lethal confrontations in the next 28 days, I think there is nearly no chance of it taking place. Sources: China Power Team. The chance of a lethal confrontation between the People’s Republic of China and any of the other countries listed does not appear to be significantly high in the next 24 days.  Any type of incident would stem from tensions regarding differing claims to the South China Sea.  Likely, such an event would happen between the People’s Republic of China and the Philippines.  China holds the world’s largest navy now, which gives them power and capability to protect their interests in the South China Sea against any other countries. “China's massive naval buildup coincides with it reinforcing its claims to almost all of the 3.3 million square-kilometer (1.3 million square-mile) South China Sea by building up tiny reefs and sandbars into man-made artificial islands heavily fortified with missiles, runways and weapons systems” (Lendon 2021).  “In response to China’s assertive presence in the disputed territory, Japan has sold military ships and equipment to the Philippines and Vietnam in order to improve their maritime security capacity and to deter Chinese aggression” (Council on Foreign Relations 2021). 
The chance for an attack is not impossible, especially considering China’s newest coast guard law. “The National People’s Congress standing committee in Beijing passed a law January 22 that expressly lets the coast guard use force. The law prescribes “all necessary means” to stop foreign vessels, including use of weapons aboard Chinese ships” (Jennings 2021).  “Vietnamese sailors died in 1974 and 1988 in military clashes with China. The two countries rammed each other’s boats in 2014 when Beijing authorized placement of a Chinese oil rig in disputed waters. China and the Philippines entered a standoff in 2012 as the Chinese side took control of a shoal west of Luzon Island. China and Malaysia were locked in their own standoff in early 2020” (Jennings 2021).  With tensions high, and disputes long-standing, something could spark a reaction from one country or another, but a lethal confrontation may not ensue. Seeing this, I feel fair to predict a 30% likelihood.  Council on Foreign Relations. (2021). As China continues to assert its claim to areas within the 9-dash line in the South China Sea, the pressure is mounting on its southern neighbors. China projects power through its artificial  islands that serve as staging bases for aircraft, warships, and maritime vessels. For a country like Malaysia who is conducting resource exploration in disputed waters, China's expansion represents a direct challenge to their territorial claims. Other tensions have manifested with Indonesia deploying fighter jets and naval ships to deter Chinese fishing in its waters and Chinese vessels sake a Vietnamese fishing boat in vicinity of the Paracel Islands. China's strategy is to slowly wear down the opposition to its territorial claims (Wescott & Lendon, 2020). Since the 1970s, Southeast Asian states have squabbled over the territorial claims to land masses and navigation rights in the South China Sea. China leverages its nine-dash line claims to argue its claims to sovereignty, yet other nations such as the US argue, that freedom of navigation is not trumped by claims to economic exchange zones (EEZs). Washington has interests in maintaining freedom of navigation in the area and provides backing to countries such as the Philippines and Taiwan (CFR, 2021). China uses the US commitment to rules of engagement of the law of war to its advantage. Instead of deterring US warships with the military, China hires fishermen and other non-governmental vessels to harass its neighbors in the region. This strategy effectively avoids the prospect of conflict, offers Beijing plausible deniability, and great political risk of a neighboring country's ship fires on one of the vessels as it would appear an attack on innocent civilians (Gady, 2015). 

	China values stability as a top priority. Making war with neighboring states would certainly destabilize the southeast Asian economies. Alternatively, China employs a long game of incremental aggression that rarely crosses the threshold of conflict that would warrant an escalation of force. The risk of lethal conflict as a result of defensive aggression from  Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam is also unlikely. Although some leaders in Vietnam and Indonesia have attempted to confront Beijing on its incursions, these nations value stability as well and thus would prefer a diplomatic solution to armed conflict. China will not hesitate to retaliate against one of these nations if the US ceases to back them. If the US departs, then the chances for conflict increase as China will capitalize on the power vacuum left behind to secure its national interests in the Sea.

Brunei- (2pts) Potentially due to their dependence on China for funding. Brunei's populace has been showing frustration with the Sultan due to the sluggish economy, corruption, and unemployment. With Brunei being a key node in the Belt and Road Initiative, they could be vulnerable in the future for occupation by China to gain more of a foothold in the SCS. However, I think it's highly unlikely that will happen before the end of the month. 
Indonesia- (3 pts) 2016- holding Chinese fisherman in a dispute with China over the fisherman claiming they were in "Chinese traditional fishing grounds." China has discouraged Indonesia from joining countries that challenge China's territorial claims. 2020- Indonesians captured two Chinese vessels after one of them had a dead Indonesian Fisherman on it. 
Malaysia- (1 pt) Even though Malaysia's territorial claims overlap with China, they don't seem to be concerned with debating the issue. Placid relations with China could change with the election of Muhyiddin Yassin. 
The Philippines (1 pt)- tensions between China and the Philippines due to Chinese ships surveying the Benham Rise. The Chinese claim that their intentions are purely for research. The UN recognizes Indonesia's claim to the resource-rich Benham Rise undersea plateau. 
Singapore (1 pt)- "Mr. Lee laid out Singapore’s interest in and stand on the issue, saying that while the country does not have any claims of its own in the South China Sea, and does not take sides on the specific claims of claimants, Singapore still has a lot at stake in three areas: International law, freedom of navigation and unity in ASEAN." The only reason I would justify giving Singapore a point would be in the event they discover oil in a potentially contested area.
Vietnam (11 pts) - If there's any country that will most likely have a conflict with China over the next month, it's Vietnam. The two countries have had multiple standoffs in the last ten years. Numerous instances of Chinese vessels ramming and sinking Vietnamese vessels have been reported. With the inclusion of cyberattacks on Vietnam from China, I would wager that the likelihood of an attack on Vietnam from China is higher than any of the other countries. I'm giving this a 10% chance for the simple fact of the previous issues between the two countries in the contested areas around the Paracel Islands. Also, an additional point just because it's another country on the list that could potentially conflict with China. 
When it comes to the South China Sea, China is focused on expanding their territory, and they know the real threat to their success is the United States. Since 2015 Xi Xinping has focused heavily on developing China's Navy. Now with the largest navy in the world, China is poised to defend the territory they think belongs to them. The sheer number of their vessels (360) sounds daunting, but the US Navy still has better manpower, more experience, and better training. Additionally, US ships are armed more heavily.  (2 pts) The only reason I could imagine China attacking one of the mentioned countries by the end of the month would be if one of them struck oil in their claimed territory. That would influence China to jump on the prospect of obtaining the resource for themselves. Since 1970 no country in South East Asia has struck a large enough oil reserve to fight for. It's unlikely to happen this month, but I'm still going to give it a few percentage points just on the possibility that it does happen. Considering the U.S.’s ramping up of operations in the South China Sea (SCS) since President Biden took office (Lendon, 2021), there would be more likelihood of a China-U.S. confrontation as compared to a confrontation of China and the other nations who are claimants of the SCS. However, China passed a new Coast Guard Law on January 22, 2021, which “empowers the force to ‘take all necessary measures, including the use of weapons, when national sovereignty, sovereign rights, and jurisdiction are being illegally infringed upon by foreign organizations or individuals at sea’” (Philippines protests new China law as `verbal threat of war’, 2021). Considering the actions that China has already taken in the SCS, and the fact that it claims most of the SCS as being within its territory, this new law creates a much higher likelihood of China sparking conflict in the SCS against rivals including Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam. I gauge that the overall threat is low but probable within the timeframe of this prediction, however long-term is a whole nother story. Lendon, B. (2021, February 17). The territorial disputes in the South China Sea involve the states of China, the Philippines, Brunei, Malaysia, and Vietnam. The Spratly and Paracel Islands, specifically, are the source of increasing contention. China’s island-building and land reclamation efforts based on claims of historical sovereignty encroach on the territorial islands and waters of these South Asian states. Indonesia and Singapore assert they are non-claimants in the South China Sea disputes. Confrontations stemming from these disputes have involved police/military forces of the respective country’s sovereign waters and the fishing vessels of other claimants who entered the waters. The coast guards of various claimants have encountered each other and used intimidation tactics as well . However, there has not been a lethal confrontation between the respective militia/military forces/law enforcement of the claimants yet. There is a factor that may diminish the possibility of a future lethal confrontation. On November 15th, 2020, ASEAN member states and five regional partners – including China – signed the Regional Comprehensive Economic Plan (RCEP). According to Brookings’ simulations, “RCEP could add $209 billion annually to world incomes, and $500 billion to world trade by 2030.” Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Vietnam signed RCEP. On one hand, because this agreement is so valuable, their membership could diminish the possibility of an intentional clash with China’s military. The agreement promotes ASEAN centrality in the Indo-Pacific and strengthens these countries’ relationships with China. On the other hand, this agreement may embolden China in its maritime strategy of off-shore balancing in the East and South China Seas. The strategy is committed to securing China’s “land and littoral frontiers” (which includes the nine-dash line and Taiwan), consolidating influence in China’s near seas (which include Vietnam and Thailand), and maintaining a balance of power which favors China. The agreement, therefore, could provide a certain level of peace, but also encourage China to increase its maritime activities.  It seems unlikely a lethal military/armed confrontation will occur among these countries before April 1st. Assuming this agreement eases tensions between the South Asian claimants and China – as well as decreases these activities in the South China Sea – I give this scenario a possibility score of 1%.
Lowering my forecast by 1% as we get closer to the deadline.

While US presence in the area has helped deter some of the saber rattling that China and Indonesia seem to be fond of in the area, I don't think there is a high chance that it will escalate before the first of the month. However, I would be loathe to say it wouldn't happen as all parties involved utilize the area of the South China Sea and make pot shots at each other in attempts to intimidate the opposition out; accidents do happen.

Even though altercations like this have occurred it is still extremely unlikely that a deadly conflict between Republic of China national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel will happen before 1 April 2021. Which is why I gave this situation a 0% chance of happening. This is something that might happen eventually but not this soon.

While China just recently enacted a coast guard law explicitly allowing its coast guard vessels to fire on foreign vessels (https://gcaptain.com/u-s-concerned-chinas-new-coast-guard-law-could-escalate-maritime-disputes/) it is still highly unlikely that there will be a lethal confrontation between the Republic of China national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel before 1 April 2021. China does not seek military conflict with its neighbors and has been focused on fostering cooperation through the pandemic. A lethal confrontation between China and the forces of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Singapore and/or Vietnam is not currently in China’s best interest or those of the other countries. With tensions high in the South China Sea, action taken is highly coordinated and calculated in order to prevent broader conflict.

As some other predictions have pointed out, we are currently going through a worldwide pandemic that has had a significant effect on global trade. A lethal confrontation or an escalation that would lead to increasing tensions would not be advisable for any of the parties listed above. China might be performing naval exercises in the South China Sea, but those will most likely not lead to any confrontations. Looking at China's long-term goal, it does not intend to pursue control over nations militarily but rather economically. Its one belt-one road initiative is a prime example of how it intends to increase its influence. In addition, the date is a month away, and there tend to be signs alluding to possible lethal confrontations, which have not been seen as of yet.

The likelihood of a lethal confrontation between the national military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement personnel of the People's Republic of China and those of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam before 1 April 2021 is extremely low based off current China-ASEAN relations and recent history. In September 2020, Chinese State Councilor and Foreign Minister Wang Yi visited Myanmar, Indonesia, Brunei, and the Philippines in an effort to deepen mutual trust and promote cooperation, with Yi emphasizing that China-ASEAN relations is one of his top priorities. China and ASEAN countries have cooperated closely in a joint pandemic response, working together to develop and distribute vaccines, indicating non-hostile relations. However, over the past year, tensions have risen out of China’s aggressive behavior in the South China Sea, with Malaysia, Vietnam, and the Philippines (along with a handful of Western countries) releasing statements calling on states to follow the rule of international law. In 2020, China increased tensions between itself and Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines as the Chinese Coast Guard sank a Vietnamese fishing boat (no one was injured), a Chinese ship entered contested waters off Malaysia, and a Chinese warship aimed its weapons control radar at a Philippine naval vessel; however, no direct military conflict occurred. It is well-known that China, Vietnam, Taiwan, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Brunei are locked in an overlapping series of maritime and territorial disputes, and though tensions between China and these countries wax and wane, it seems as if China is currently focused on strengthening diplomatic relations with ASEAN countries and keeping an eye on Western powers, especially the US, who send naval assets through the South China Sea region. Additionally, China has launched a month of military exercises and closed off around 80 square kilometers in Chinese waters for the month of March, so it is likely that military attention (at least the navy) will be diverting its attention to these exercises. There is a very low likelihood of a lethal military confrontation in the next month; however, with tensions being so high, it is possible that a ship or submarine in the wrong area or a trade dispute could escalate into a lethal military conflict, which is why I am giving a 5% likelihood of occurrence.

According to the Council on Foreign Relations Global Conflict tracker, “Tensions between China and both the Philippines and Vietnam have recently cooled, even as China increased its military activity in the South China Sea by conducting a series of naval maneuvers and exercises in March and April 2018.”  With China conducting military exercises in the South China Sea for the entire month of March in a designated five-kilometer radius, as well as the presence of U.S. and French naval military vessels, China’s neighbors will likely be wary to increase tensions with the heavily preoccupied People’s Liberation Army Navy.  Since Germany is also planning to send a warship through the area, the Chinese government will likely sense increasing pressure from NATO powers and focus their attention on these issues rather than squabbles with the countries in question.  Any lethal engagements with neighboring nations in the South China Sea littoral region would likely only fuel further western pressure against China and not work to the advantage of the Chinese Communist Party, thus I suspect it is almost certain China will limit military action to their usual posturing against western naval vessels in the area.  Based on this, I am forecasting a 99% chance there will be no lethal confrontations between China and Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and/or Vietnam prior to the end of their military exercises concluding at the end of this month.  If Chinese military activity in the South China Sea does not decrease following the conclusion of this exercise, it may be indicative of intentions to conduct territorial enforcement operations which could lead to lethal confrontations like those seen from Russia in the Eastern European region, however, this is not within the bounds of this question or response and would require further research for a more informed analysis.  As a result, I am only assigning a 1% chance to the question posed.

The most likely scenario in which a lethal confrontation would occur between China and any of these countries would be in the South China Sea (SCS). China currently has an advantageous position in the SCS and therefore it is not in China's interest to instigate a confrontation. It can achieve its goals by using non-military means. Though China may perceive a change in U.S. administrations to be a vulnerability that it can take advantage of, it is more likely to try to avoid any military confrontation in the SCS and focus instead on other national interests it deems more important, such as controlling Hong Kong or the autonomous regions . While there remains a possibility for hostility between these nations, “lethal confrontation” between their "military forces" or "law enforcement" remains low.  In more than 20 years, the only fatalities in the South China Sea dispute have been civilian fishermen.  Despite strong rhetoric, shows of force, and occasional naval collisions, these nations have resolved military and/or law enforcement stand-offs peacefully. Furthermore, recent public statements from ASEAN and China indicate at least a temporary reduction in tensions.  Throughout 2020, led by a Vietnamese Chairman, ASEAN took a firm stance against Chinese maritime provocations.  However, Vietnam has a history of belligerence with China.  The incoming 2021 ASEAN chair is from Brunei, which is a historic Chinese ally.   In September 2020, China re-engaged in multilateral talks with ASEAN for a South China Sea Maritime Code of Conduct.  At this time, the Chinese Minister of Foreign Affairs referred to his desire for a “peaceful and stable South China Sea” and commitment to “address…the issue with a cool head.” A likely counterargument is that China will exploit current U.S. political turmoil to assert their autonomy early in the next Presidential Administration.  However, the Biden Administration’s public statements suggest a more cooperative approach than China experienced over the last four years.  Biden’s nominee for Secretary of State, Anthony Blinken has committed to “re-engage China and work with China.”  Jake Sullivan, the nominee for National Security Adviser, has articulated a position of “managed co-existence” with China.  While China may very well test the new administration’s resolve on the South China Sea, they are unlikely to squander the opportunity for improved relations with the U.S. by forcing a lethal confrontation with ASEAN in the Biden Administration’s first 100 days.

Although, China is steadfast in its position to exercise power on  the South China Sea, due to its importance for global trade, it is unlikely that a military conflict will ensue between China and Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Phillipines, Taiwan or Vietnam before  1 April 2021. The reason for this being that military escalation on behalf of China would attract American attention, and likely even intervention, thus deterring China from pursuing an agenda of aggression. Moreover, historically, this is not an area that is prone to military conflict. In the last 45 years, there have only been 2 military conflicts in the area between China and Vietnam. 
On June 15, however, China pursued a military conflict with India in regards to a border dispute, resulting in a few dozen deaths. This was done as a demonstration of strength on China’s part after both its reputation and economy suffered as a result of COVID-19. Despite this, it is unlikely that an escalation to this scale would occur within the South China Sea, as the repercussion would be far greater. The skirmish that took place with India was so minuscule in comparison that China even announced that it would not impact trade relations between the 2 countries.

Much of my logic is similar to the last time.  Base rate: in the last 10 years, there has been 1 lethal confrontation between China and these states, the 2014 China-Vietnam oil rig crisis, and a number of almost-lethal confrontations. This yields a per-annum base rate of 10%, and a normalized (over 8 months / 12) rate of 6.6%.  Before making adjustments to this rate, we consider potential causes for this conflict. 
- War that involves overthrowing a government. This would be something like the Vietnam war, or potentially even a war in another country in which both China and one of these states participate. 
- Border skirmishes. This is not in the South China Sea, but would still technically count as a conflict. 
- South China Sea skirmishes.  As the region has been reasonably stable in the last two decades, I assign negligible probabilities to the first two.  There are various factors that may adjust this base rate. 
- The Council on Foreign Relations identifies this problem as worsening. I shift my probability from 6.6% -> 8%. 
- The COVID factor decreases this probability. On March 23, 2020, UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres called for a global ceasefire (https://news.un.org/en/story/2020/03/1059972). While this has been unheeded in ongoing wars, (https://www.amnesty.org/en/latest/news/2020/05/as-covid-19-burns-the-worlds-forgotten-wars-continue-to-take-their-toll-on-civilians-as-well/), it would be politically incorrect for China (or any of these states) to conflict. I decrease my probability from 8% -> 5%. 
- The US factor increases this probability. The US has been increasingly concerned with China, and with elections coming up, Trump may attempt a last minute play at China. On July 13, the US State Department released a statement condemning Chinese actions in the region (https://www.state.gov/u-s-position-on-maritime-claims-in-the-south-china-sea/). If the US engages in some conflict, it is likely to involve these countries. I shift my probability from 5% -> 7%.  My final forecast is 7%.

Of course, with the coronavirus still rampant, it seems like military confrontation is still at least several months away (if at all -- much like US-Iran conflict to start out the year). All things considered, I give this a 5% chance of occurring before  the beginning of April 2021.

I previously forecasted under another account, so I figured I should update my forecast on this account.  The South China Sea is an incredibly important region to global trade, as many shipping routes travel through the area. In 2017, 40% of the world's "liquefied natural gas trade transited through the South China Sea".  In recent years, China has made a large effort to establish full control over the area; both over its lucrative fishing rights and to establish control over the shipping lanes. Americans have conducted military operations in China's EEZ, contesting the Chinese's authority over the region, and making the US’s presence in the region known. China is known to forcefully defend their territory and patrol their borders. President Xi sees the South China Sea as Chinese territory. The Council on Foreign Relations claims, "exercising full sovereignty over this area is a core component of President Xi Jinping’s 'China Dream.' China does not accept or respect the sovereignty claims of Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Taiwan, or Vietnam in this region."  China has not shied away from using lethal force to defend its borders. On the 15th of June, there was a lethal clash on the Chinese-Indian border. Exact casualty numbers are not available, but according to the NY Times, "It was the bloodiest clash on that frontier since 1967”, implying deaths in the double digits. The Chinese-Indian border is a land border, which is heavily militarized. A lethal confrontation over territorial rights in the South China Sea would certainly be a naval encounter. Historically, there have been very few lethal encounters in this region between military forces. There have been many instances of Chinese aggression resulting in deaths, but they have mostly been civilian deaths (fishermen).  The China India border is not one which concerns the global economy. The South China Sea is of far greater importance, and a military confrontation in the South China Sea would likely result in some form of American involvement, and could even lead to some sort of proxy war between the US and China. This is likely not a risk China is willing to take. In the past week, the US has denounced China's territorial claims in the region. The Americans have a large naval presence in the South China Sea. The Chinese are aware their actions in the South China Sea are under intense scrutiny. It would be incredibly unwise for the PRC to provoke the US by having a militaristic confrontation with one of the nations that claim a part of the South China Sea (Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, and Vietnam). The odds of a confrontation in the South China Sea are generally low on a monthly basis. But for a confrontation in the South China sea, between two military(!) forces and resulting in a death, the odds must be significantly lower.  Historically, there have been 2 major lethal military confrontations between China and the other South China Sea claimants (both times with Vietnam). These occurred in 1974 and 1988. There have been multiple conflicts over this timeframe involving civilian deaths(typically fisherman). A civilian base rate of 20% annually is roughly appropriate, with one death every five years. A militaristic base rate of ~4% annually seems appropriate, based on this historic data (2 encounters in 50 years).  As mentioned, tensions are currently high, which increases the chance of a lethal confrontation. 
However, because of the American presence in the region, repercussions of aggression will be intense, lessening the likelihood of a conflict. Because of these main two forces, I believe the probability of a lethal, militaristic conflict is about 45bp each month, or 1.5x the militaristic base rate. This implies a probability of 4% in the next nine months. Sources:

As others have established fairly extensively, the base rate is in the neighborhood of 5%.  On top of this base rate, I think that there are a couple of important factors to consider.  First, China has demonstrated recently that it is quite willing to push on the boundaries of international approval, especially as it comes to its territorial control.  There was the lethal clash between Chinese and Indian soldiers, as well as the assertion of Chinese authority over Hong Kong in spite of international agreements and disapproval.  Further, tension has been growing in the area of the South China Sea recently, with China increasing its activities there, as well as the United States conducting military exercises.  I think that the demonstration of China's willingness to risk international sanction increases the likelihood fo a lethal conflict, as does increasing activity in the South China Sea.  However, I think that the strong US military presence in the area works against there being a lethal conflict, as China will be unwilling to risk a direct military conflict with a major trading partner and nuclear power.  Because of this, I think that the US military exercises meaningfully reduce the chance of a lethal conflict in the area.  All together, I believe that the chance of a lethal conflict is slightly higher than the base rate, though primarily because of the possibility of the US pulling out of the area. My forecast drops slightly lower, as I ingest new evidence of the rareness of such events. My original forecast involved some basic mathematical thinking; If there is a 1% chance of each month of such a confrontation, then there is about a 10-20% chance. However, this was based only on information I had at the time. Now, I have an idea of the reference class - we have only seen one such violent incident in the past 20 years, and a few close to lethal incidents as well. Given the very small number of samples (and non-stationary distribution), unfortunately these may not be representative of the future. However, for now assuming that they are to some extent, this implies 0.05 expected incidents / year, and with high likelihood a <20% chance/year of an incident (modelled as binomial). Due to the high variance of this estimate, it would be in my best interest to bias my predicted probability slightly higher than the sample mean of about 5-10% in order to limit downside from an undesired binary outcome. This estimate requires adjustments - China has gained power and become more politically aggressive over the years. Land claims in the South China Sea and various disputes with Southeast-asian countries have lasted for a while, and could produce violence in the future. In addition, we're in a time of higher regional tension in South/East Asia than 12-20 years ago (Taiwan-China, Hong Kong, North Korea-US). Due to this uncertainty, I have adjusted the sample probability estimate higher in order to account for regime changes.
Base rate + number of near lethal confrontations

Prior for lethal cases is one happening in the last twenty years or so, so assuming linearity throughout you'll be seeing around something between 5% as a lower bound. As an upper bound, lets say that of the 20 other nonlethal confrontations across the past two decades each one has only around a 5% also of being lethal, and given our Bayes that of the past 20 only one has been lethal, the number of distributions of 21 choose 2 being lethal is approximately less than double the number of distributions of only 1 of the 21 being lethal. So, we slightly less than double this 5% rate to get 8%.

There has been one lethal confrontation in the past 20 years, when Chinese ships attacked two Vietnamese fishing boats, killing 9 people in 2005. This sets a base rate of 5% chance of lethal confrontations per year. Assuming that there is no seasonality to this base rate probability, and that our time frame exists from July 5 - April 1 2021, that is approximately, 9 months. Thus, in the remaining time of the forecast, I operate on a prior of 3.75%. However, there have been some trends that suggest that there may be a higher chance of confrontation looming. The China-India border conflict in June demonstrates that China is more than willing to take action in border disputes. Additionally, due to USA warships entering the South China Sea, a statement was issued stating that China is ready to fire anti-cruise missiles to sink these ships, with China wishing to establish control over the sea. Moreover, even amidst COVID, reports show that China has been increasing its patrols and naval exercises in the South China Sea. As a result of these notions, as well as recognizing that my base rate does not include any near lethal encounters (such as China sinking the fishing vessels from the Philippines in April 2020), I am inclined to double my base rate to 7.5%. Since GJO does not take decimals, I rounded up due to the upward bias from recent news.

There have been very few incidents of lethal confrontation between China and these countries in the last twenty years, giving a base rate of about 15%, including close calls. However, the (large) majority of these cases were not between national military forces, militia and/or law enforcement personnel, but rather involved fishermen. This gives a new base rate of 5% (1 event), which I adjusted to reflect the 8 months remaining to April 1, 2021. The Covid-19 crisis skews this estimate down, as it is unlikely that either countries would begin a conflict during a pandemic. Probability of lethal conflict (i.e. non-civilian fatalities) between China and… 1.	Brunei = 0%
2.	Indonesia = <1%

This only covers fatalities in military forces, militia and/or law enforcement on either side. Civilian casualties are implicitly discounted. This is an important distinction, as it means that even significant violent events (such as Chinese CG vessels ramming/sinking fishing boats) wouldn’t count. For a lethal confrontation to occur therefore, a number of events would have to occur to escalate the situation. Here is an example of a possible chain of events: -	Competing claims on economic/strategic/political rights to an area. ->
->	Presence of civilians from one/more competitors (i.e. fishing fleets/oil & gas representatives). ->
->	Presence of Coast Guard or Navy to guard nation’s civilians/stop opponent’s civilians (delete as appropriate). ->
->	Consequent presence of opponent’s CG or Navy to guard nation’s rights/stop opponent’s interference (delete as appropriate). ->
->	Escalation of conflict to violence (either against civilians or directly against opponent) e.g. by ramming ships or warning shots. ->
->	Return of violence by opponent. ->
->	Fatality within military forces, militia, and/or law enforcement (the civilians don’t count unfortunately). As you can see, this is quite a long chain of events, and as it specifies death of a combatant rather than civilian it actually excludes most fatalities that may semi/un-intentionally result from in-the-moment aggression. It would require both states to deliberately send in their armed forces, then one or both of those groups to actively target each other. As such, I have distinguished between the probability of violent clashes between countries and non-civilian fatalities. Assessment by country: 1.	Brunei 
Sometimes referred to as a “silent claimant” to the South China Sea, Brunei’s EEZ covers a number of maritime features, but the kingdom claims only Louisa Reef which lies upon its continental shelf. Because Louisa Reef is part of the Spratly islands, that feature is also claimed by China and Vietnam.
Brunei is the only claimant state that does not occupy any maritime features or maintain a military presence in the region. Predominantly for this reason, the likelihood of armed clashes between the two states’ forces is vanishingly unlikely. Violent Clashes = 1-2%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = 0% 2.	Indonesia 
Indonesia has long maintained its neutrality and claimed to have no maritime disputes with China. Despite Indonesia’s position as a non-claimant state in the SC Sea dispute however, more frequent clashes and a hardening approach from China has forced a shift in attitude in recent years.
2016 – Three confrontations between Chinese fishing boats and the Indonesian Navy, including at least one where they fired warning shots; China’s foreign ministry said one boat was damaged and one sailor shot & injured.
January 2020 – Stand-off between Chinese Coast Guard ships escorting fishing boats and five Indonesian warships and F16s off the coast of Indonesia. Indonesia is still cautious about escalating tensions however.
Despite some conflict, the overall lack of direct opportunities for direct clashes (due to few/zero competing geographic claims) combined with Indonesia’s unwillingness to escalate tensions with a growing trade partner suggests that this is unlikely to escalate to state-on-state conflict. Violent Clashes = 1-2%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = <1% 3.	Malaysia 
Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said that China was not a threat to anyone in the South China Sea dispute and was not worried about aggression from China, accusing the United States of provoking China and trying to turn China's neighbours against China.
This line has hardened in recent years however, with Malaysia being involved in a stand-off with a Chinese survey ship and Chinese Coast Guard vessels. Events escalated in April, when a stand-off occurred between Malaysia, Vietnam, China and the US simultaneously, thus increasing the possibility of an armed clash.
https://oilprice.com/Latest-Energy-News/World-News/China-And-Malaysia-Clash-In-Highly-Disputed-South-China-Sea.html
https://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3051889/malaysia-china-and-vietnam-dangerous-ongoing-game-chicken-south Violent Clashes = 15-20%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = 1-2% 4.	Philippines 
April 2012 – Scarborough Shoal standoff between Philippine Navy & PRC Coastguard
May 2013 - A Taiwanese fisherman was machine gunned to death by the coast guard of the Philippines. Although not PRC, it does indicate a willingness to use violence.
July 2016 – UNCLOS panel unanimously ruled in favour of Philippines in dispute over china’s claim on territories within the nine-dash line. China has rejected the ruling.
June 2019 - 22 Filipino fishermen were left floating after a Chinese vessel rammed and sank their boat, abandoning them to the sea.
The large number of incidents is mitigated by Duerte’s recognition of strategic reality on the ground and consequently his unwillingness to escalate a conflict that would result in the Philippines’ “annihilation” (https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/1233091/south-china-sea-duterte-philippines-annihilation-beijing-grip-tightens-spt). Furthermore in December 2019 China and the Philippines finally agreed to cooperate in the South China Sea, pursuing joint oil & gas exploration, thus removing much of the impetus that might lead to conflict. Therefore, although the risk of a clash may have be high in the recent past, the risk a direct conflict between the two states’ forces resulting in a fatality is quite low.  Violent Clashes = 10%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = 1% 5.	Singapore 
Historically the two countries have quite close economic and political ties, in no small part due to Singapore’s significant population of ethnic Han Chinese. 
In 2016 China seized 9 armoured vehicles that Singapore had shipped through Hong Kong on their return from a training exercise on Taiwan. This marked the low point in C/S relations however, and Singapore did not retaliate. The two are strongly linked economically and are sufficiently far enough from each other that territorial disputes of the type felt with Vietnam and the Philippines are unlikely.
https://www.fpri.org/article/2019/12/the-odd-couple-singapores-relations-with-china/ Violent Clashes = <1%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = ~0% 6.	Vietnam 
Vietnam has been the strongest proponent against China’s territorial claims in the South China Sea in recent years. Hanoi’s frustration is intensifying as Beijing becomes even more aggressive in the South China Sea. In January 2020 it released a defence White Paper suggesting a more formal hardening of that stance and even a shift into the US’ sphere of influence to counter China’s rising assertiveness.
2014-2015 - Exchanges of fire across China/Vietnam land border.
April 2020 - Vietnamese fishing boat sank after it collided with a Chinese Coastguard ship near Vietnamese oil rig by the Paracel Islands. 
https://www.cfr.org/report/china-vietnam-military-clash  Violent Clashes = 25-30%
Non-Civilian Fatalities = 3-5%

Most of the forecasting community will state that the sheer size of the Chinese Navy will deter the forces of the 4 major front line countries in Malaysia, Indonesia, Vietnam or the Philippines. The Sino-Vietnamese war of ‘79 and the Battle of the Paracel islands took place before globalization took hold. China and Vietnam since then willfully accepted participation on the big stage to benefit and prosper economically. They wanted a slice of the proverbial pie.   Getting seconds means walking back on that stage in the spotlight, with economic sanctions waiting if the thin red line is crossed.  Russia’s care or concern for economic sanctions is nonexistent, and the little green Spetsnaz soldiers proved Crimea was more critical to expanding power projection or crossing some singular economic juncture with its Black Sea natural gas fields, as opposed to a multifaceted global trade strategy. The SCS shares some characteristics with the Black Sea, in its near billion barrel expected gas reserves and highly lucrative fishing grounds.  The region is a gold mine surrounded by demand with no end in sight.   The Chinese have a fleet of maritime militia and Coast guard boats that harass Vietnamese and Phillipine vessels.  The Vietnamese also have armed maritime militia boats capable of peaceful fishing activities or conversion to vessels of defense as needed.   They are the Dan Quan Bien.  Fish boat rammings USUALLY occur when the Vietnamese or Phillipine vessels are caught fishing between May 16 and August.  The Chinese recognize the need for some level of conservation before all the biological resources are depleted.  Water cannons have been used in the past, along with boat rammings, neither of which led to military response. Malaysian state owned Petronas sent an exploratory vessel, the West Capella, just beyond its 200 mile economic exclusion zone.  For many days the vessel was “harassed”.  Harassment and armed attack are two completely different types of threats, and escalation into a two or greater clash of naval vessels would certainly lead to greater US activity in the SCS.  And China is fully aware the size of the US submarine and potential drone submarine fleet. The only possibility of battle I see is if Malaysia were to find proven oil or gas reserves. For starters, it's notable that the vast majority of the lethal confrontations in this dispute (last 10 years) have been lethal force by military personnel against non-military personnel, which lethal force would not meet the criteria above. [1] Based some quick wikipedia searching, for most of these countries, lethal confrontation between national military personnel and that of China is a once-in-several-decades occurrence, and/or unprecedented in the last several decades [2]. Total WAG on the base rate is that the range of probabilities for each individual country is somewhere between close to zero and P=0.05, with the mean being somewhere around P=0.01. With this WAG, therefore, the probability that at least one lethal confrontation takes place is P=1-(1-0.01)^6=0.058. I don't see any strong signals to deviate one way or another from that base rate. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_South_China_Sea_dispute#2010
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Territorial_disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea#Disputes_in_the_South_China_Sea_region

There will be a lethal confrontation between the PRC and the respective other nations, but it will probably not happen before 1 April 2021. The PRC's party and their leadership is very patient, and they seem to be very aware whether they have reached supremacy in a field or not, and which of their neighbors could be useful for other purposes or as allies in other conflicts. While Singapore seems highly likely to end up just like Hong Kong for the aim of China dominating marine transportation and monopolize ports and trade in that region, a conflict is likely to happen not this year, and not next year, maybe not even in this decade.
As soon as China has got a lever for a political refurbishment in their dooryard, they will use it. Until then, they will try to create dependencies through co-operation.
